awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding the Long-Run Effects of School Desegregation on Political and Social Preferences
awd_abstract_narration:
Busing was one of the two main ways through which public schools were desegregated in the post-Civil Rights era. While the effects of busing on educational outcomes have been studied, not much is known about the long term effects of busing on political ideology and social interactions.  This research project will use historical data combined with a large survey data to study the long-run effects of busing on political, ideology, and racial attitudes of those who actually experienced busing.  This study uses data from the “Louisville Experiment” in which a lottery system was used to assign some white students to be bused to minority schools for two years while others were bused for one year with others not being bused at al.  The researchers use this variation is busing assignment across different cohorts and between groups of students to study the effects of busing on political attitudes.  This research results will provide a broader understanding of the effects of busing and its unintended effects generally.


This research project combines archival data, a large survey data, and a difference-in-difference estimation strategy to estimate the causal impact of being bused on political preferences forty-five years later using a natural experiment from the mid-1970s in Louisville, KY.  The “Louisville Experiment” assigned students to be  bused at different ages based on the first letter of their last name. For the initial cohorts of whites, this resulted in some students being assigned to two years of busing while others received only one year or no busing. Using this variation across cohorts and between groups of students with different last names, the research project will estimate the long-run causal impact of busing on political preferences and attitudes. Specifically, the PIs use difference-in-difference methods to estimate the causal effects of busing on partisanship, voter turn-out, and political donations.  The research will also investigate the effects of busing on racial attitudes and support for income support programs.  The results of this research will provide a better understanding of the long-term broader impacts of integration programs.  It could inform policies to improve racial integration and probably improve social harmony.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

This research investigates the long-term socio-political impacts of school desegregation policies in the United States, focusing on the court-mandated desegregation program implemented in Jefferson County, Kentucky, in 1975. By utilizing a quasi-randomized natural experiment where students were assigned to busing schedules based on the first letter of their last names, the study examines the lasting effects of attending inner-city schools on political participation and preferences among white students.

The findings demonstrate that exposure to inner-city school environments significantly increased the likelihood of individuals supporting the Democratic Party and its candidates more than 40 years later. Additionally, these individuals exhibited a decreased belief in a "just world," indicating a shift toward recognizing systemic inequalities. The study posits a poverty-centered version of the contact hypothesis, suggesting that exposure to economic deprivation sensitizes individuals to issues of inequality and fairness. These results contribute to our understanding of the long-term effects of desegregation policies on ideology, attitudes, and political alignment, bridging gaps in existing literature on educational interventions and their social impacts.

Broader Impacts

The research underscores the enduring societal consequences of policy-driven desegregation efforts. By highlighting the role of early-life exposure to socio-economic diversity in shaping adult political ideologies, the study provides evidence for the importance of equitable educational policies in promoting long-term societal cohesion and awareness of inequality. This work has implications for policymakers, educators, and social scientists seeking to design interventions that foster greater empathy and understanding across socio-economic divides.

Additionally, the project employed innovative methodologies by linking historical high school yearbook data to contemporary voter registration records and conducting original surveys of affected individuals. This approach exemplifies how interdisciplinary methods can be leveraged to evaluate long-term policy impacts.

Key Findings

  1. Political Alignment: Individuals bused to inner-city schools were 3% more likely to register as Democrats decades later, compared to non-bused peers.
  2. Ideological Shifts: Bused individuals demonstrated significantly lower belief in a "just world" and greater support for redistributive policies, indicating a lasting change in ideological outlook.
  3. Mechanisms: Survey responses revealed that the shifts were driven by increased exposure to economic deprivation rather than racial integration alone, challenging traditional interpretations of the contact hypothesis.
  4. White Flight: The study documented increased white flight from public schools following the implementation of desegregation, suggesting that resistance to integration policies influenced educational choices.

Public Engagement and Dissemination

The findings have been disseminated through presentations at major academic conferences, including the American Economic Association and the European Economic Association, as well as seminars at universities across the United States and internationally. The research team has also shared insights with educators and policymakers to inform discussions on equity in education.

Through collaboration with archival institutions and community groups, the project has enhanced public understanding of the historical and contemporary relevance of desegregation policies. Future outreach efforts include policy briefs and public lectures aimed at broadening the accessibility of these findings.

Acknowledgments

We express our sincere gratitude to the numerous research assistants whose contributions have been instrumental in the success of this project. Their involvement as research assistants has provided them with important exposure to cutting-edge research methodologies and techniques. We have been honored to deliver numerous seminars worldwide, showcasing the findings from this research to esteemed researchers at prestigious institutions.

We are extremely grateful for the generous support extended to us by the NSF.
